# Rest (physics)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/40px-Edit-clear.svg.png) | This article's **tone or style may not reflect the[encyclopedic tone](/wiki/Wikipedia:Writing_better_articles#Tone "Wikipedia:Writing better articles") used on Wikipedia**. See Wikipedia's [guide to writing better articles](/wiki/Wikipedia:Writing_better_articles#Tone "Wikipedia:Writing better articles") for suggestions. _(January 2013)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_  
---|---  
  
**Rest** , in [physics](/wiki/Physics "Physics"), refers to an object being
[stationary](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Stationary "wikt:Stationary")
relative to a particular [frame of reference](/wiki/Frame_of_reference "Frame
of reference") or another object. When the position of a body with respect to
its surroundings does not change with [time](/wiki/Time "Time") it is said to
be "at rest". According to the [theory of
relativity](/wiki/Theory_of_relativity "Theory of relativity"), it is said
that an object is "at rest relative to" another. For example, a train
[decelerates](/wiki/Acceleration "Acceleration") approaching a station and
eventually comes to rest alongside the platform. The train can be said to be
"at rest with respect to the station", or, as the correct frame of reference
is usually implicit and/or provided by context, simply "at rest".

Given an [inertial frame of reference](/wiki/Inertial_frame_of_reference
"Inertial frame of reference"), [Newton's first law of
motion](/wiki/Newton%27s_laws_of_motion "Newton's laws of motion") states that
an object at rest will remain at rest, while the
[motion](/wiki/Motion_\(physics\) "Motion \(physics\)") of a moving object
will remain unchanged until acted upon by an [external
force](/w/index.php?title=External_force&action=edit&redlink=1 "External force
\(page does not exist\)").[1][2] An object at rest, therefore, can be
described as without [velocity](/wiki/Velocity "Velocity") and
[acceleration](/wiki/Acceleration "Acceleration") – although, according to
relativity, an object is either at rest or in motion relative to other moving
objects. The concept of "relative rest" is closely linked to that of [inertial
observers](/wiki/Inertial_frame_of_reference "Inertial frame of reference")
and the statement that nothing is at absolute rest is loosely equivalent to
stating that there are no frames of reference which are truly inertial. So-
called non-inertial observers are addressed by the theory of [general
relativity](/wiki/General_relativity "General relativity").

In reality, there is nothing at [absolute](/wiki/Absolute_time_and_space
"Absolute time and space") rest. For example, [Earth](/wiki/Earth "Earth")'s
[gravitation](/wiki/Gravity_of_Earth "Gravity of Earth") constantly pulls
objects toward its surface, while Earth is one of the objects the
[Sun](/wiki/Sun "Sun") constantly pulls towards itself, causing it to orbit
the Sun; the Sun, in turn, orbits the center of the [Milky
Way](/wiki/Milky_Way "Milky Way"); and so on.Two or more than two objects are
said to be at rest,if its position with respect to each other is not changing
or moving with uniform velocity with respect to each other.Rest and motion are
relative term.

## References[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rest_\(physics\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: References")]

  1. **Jump up ^** ["Newton's first law"](http://www.physicsclassroom.com/class/newtlaws/Lesson-1/Newton-s-First-Law). The Physics classroom. 2014-03-20.
  2. **Jump up ^** ["Newton's First Law of Motion"](https://www.grc.nasa.gov/www/k-12/airplane/newton1g.html). _www.grc.nasa.gov_. Retrieved 2016-02-09.

qa.question: when can we say that an object is at rest
qa.answer: ['When the position of a body with respect to its surroundings does not change with time']

nq_1548_2.Query Analysis: The query asks for the conditions under which an object can be considered at rest.
nq_1548_2.Query Keywords Extraction: object, at rest, position, change, time
nq_1548_2.Answer Analysis: The answer states that an object is at rest when its position relative to its surroundings does not change over time.
nq_1548_2.Document Content Analysis: The document discusses the concept of rest in physics, emphasizing that rest is relative and not absolute. It mentions that objects are at rest relative to each other if their positions do not change or if they move with uniform velocity relative to each other. It also references Newton's first law and the idea of inertial frames of reference.
nq_1548_2.Document and Query Keywords Matching: The document mentions 'object', 'at rest', 'position', and 'change', which are key terms from the query.
nq_1548_2.Document and Answer Keywords Matching: The document includes phrases like 'position with respect to each other is not changing', which aligns with the answer's definition of rest.
nq_1548_2.Key Information Matching: The document provides a detailed explanation of the concept of rest, including the idea that rest is relative and depends on the frame of reference. This matches the key information required by the query and the answer.
nq_1548_2.Can the Document Answer the Query: Yes, the document directly provides the definition of when an object is at rest, matching the answer.
nq_1548_2.Can the Document Help Infer Additional I: Yes, the document offers additional context about the relativity of rest and references to Newton's first law, which enhances understanding of the concept.
nq_1548_2.Explanation: The document is directly related to the query and provides the exact definition of when an object is at rest, as well as additional useful context about the relativity of rest and inertial frames of reference. This makes it highly relevant to the query.
